comments.commentBody: This is true.   On the other hand, the FBI may have concluded that the actions discussed in the emails were not actually illegal, but that does not mean that the voters might not find them unseemly and distasteful.
Barry, I looked at the PDF version. It has circles. But it doesn't matter. I don't like anything but a grid, an ordinary, everyday crossword puzzle grid.

Barry --

http://www.nytimes.com/svc/crosswords/v2/puzzle/12042.pdf

Colin Powell has publicly and vehemently denied he gave Hillary Clinton any such advice:

http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/colin-powell-blasts-hillary-clintons-team...
More than 1-2 percent of whites voting for Trump is shameful.
I voted for JFK the first time I came of age.  JFK, LBJ and Clinton were of better character than Nixon.  Nixon had much to offer but his paranoia did him in.

Trump has nothing to do with the KKK, nice try, though. And no one ever accused him of being ultra-conservative. Too bad the DNC didn't wake up and promoted a pathological liar while actively throwing Bernie Sanders onto the dung heap.

Yes, you do need to wake up!   Hillary is corrupt to the core.  After the elections; she will be indicted under RICO and other charges.  Get your head out of the sand.  The left wing liberal media is slaughtering Trump with twisted, distorted, manipulated, and flat out lies rather than speaking the truth.    The left wing liberal media is making up their own stories on Trump which are not base on fact rather their own fictional stories.

Oh please. Here we have Donald Trump, with his dubious background deals, questionable relations with pro-Russian, NRA and ultra-conservative lobbies... Not to mention his close relationship to racist organizations like the Ku Klux Klan -- and is that supposed to be so much better for America????
Be honest for a minute.
We might not have a saint for running for President -- but do we really need one who is ready to lynch, or incarcerate half of it???
WAKE-UP AMERICA.

The e-mail investigation hasn't ever been about something "sinister" Clinton supposedly did. That (sounds like) Clinton Foundation stuff, I think it makes sense to consider them separately.

The object of the F.B.I.'s investigation into Clinton's e-mail server, as I understand it, was to find if she violated any laws concerning the handling of classified information. I believe the relevant statute is in Title 18 of the U.S. Code, Section 793 (f) (https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/793). It seems to me that Clinton is in violation according to the basic sense of the text. I'm not a lawyer, so I've looked online for some kind of explanation. I haven't found anything addressing that point of law.

Unrelatedly: Truth is always compelling, and never boring. Correctness may be slight, because it doesn't have to carry the undeniable force of the phenomena.

Something tells me that if Sanders had become the candidate, he'd be the one peppered with FOIA requests and FBI investigations. A socialist, no less! That in itself is treasoness to the rabid right. And at his age, I'm pretty sure they'd be able to create unfounded health issues. Sanders should praise himself lucky he escaped that kind of backstabbing and slander.
No known baggage with Bernie, whereas all kinds of untrustworthiness with the Clintons including but not limited to the Clinton Foundation, DNC's involvement with her nomination etc.

With October surprize in the offing promised by Wikileaks coupled with these emails, and is Donald looking forward for a good october? I do not think so. I only wish the Republicans would have been smarter in their choice of the candidate for Presidency. DNC machine is corrupt and now they have only themselves to blame as they openly sided with the 'not trustworthy' candidate.

Bernie, where are you when we need you?
Why is it a problem for her if it wasn't for Condoleeza Rice and Colin Powell?  Oh right, they are Republicans so allowed to do anything.
The big banks and corporations know that you can't give out "chump change" in the "pay to play" world of presidential politics.

@Ilya. The only thing wrong with your comment is that there is no evidence that anyone "bought" access to HRC. The Crown Prince of Bahrain doesn't need to buy access to the US Sec. of State. He's the kind of prominent world leader who could meet with her regardless of anything else he might have done.  The other "smoking gun" from this article has an exec. from the Clinton Foundation *asking* for a meeting, an aid to Sec. Clinton (note: *not* Hillary Clinton, herself; there's not a scintilla of evidence that Clinton, herself, even knew about any of this) saying, "I'm not comfortable with this," and the exec. then saying, "Then don't ask."  This is the best the right-wing hit squad Judicial Watch can do?  This is "buying" access? A request for a meeting that both the aid and the Foundation exec *decline* to arrange?  I mean: really?

Donors to the Clinton Foundation buying access to HRC, is worse than donors to a SuperPAC buying access to its favored candidate... why again?  Republicans support unlimited donations to SuperPACs, including from corporations.

The email server issue is in a different league...she was a cabinet level officer who used a personal server for government business. That is potentially quite serious and certainly thumbs its nose at the freedom of information act and the federal records act at the very least. And she was less than forthcoming saying the emails were not classified when in fact some of them were. If she is as smart as they say she  is why couldn't she figure out how (or ask for help) to set up a separate personal email account on her phone? The reason is that she thinks she's above it all and that the rules don't apply to her. Foreign donations to her foundation? No conflict of interest there, right? It's no wonder she has such low approval ratings. Her saving grace this time around is she running against a candidate who is more flawed than she is.
Same place as Hillary's speeches to Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, etc. All locked away.....
Nonpersonal emails generated by a Secretary of State belong to the public. That's true whether the SOS is a man or a woman.
Trump has already handed over his tax returns.  To the IRS.   Hillary is the one who tried to keep her emails from her own government.

AA - Hillary WAS the government and acting in a way that probably protected some information.  Where was the outrage when Powell or Rice did it?  It almost isn’t worth responding anymore.  Flags are planted.

Where is the pressure on Trump to release his tax returns? Can they too be released, say, just before the election? When women asked for equal treatment, we meant it.

So entirely sick of this email story appearing as if there was something there. Nothing there, at all. In fact, that she went to Powell and asked for advice shows 1) working across the aisle and 2) concern and protection for the office/job. For those who want a Judge stepping in after the FBI already stepped out, it’s just reality tv mentality. Honestly, turn it off now please.
Yeah, definitely worth 8 investigations costing tens of millions of taxpayer dollars only to all tell us the same thing: that she did nothing wrong. Yawn.
There were certainly no paid speeches to the tune of $200,000 a pop either. Those were clearly made up by the "Republican spin".

There is no Scandal here.   Stop insinuating as much in your headers.  There was no Benghazi, there was no White Water,  there is no Clinton Foundation scandal there is only thirty years of Republican spin.
I think Thomas Steinbeck was intellectually disabled.

Misha - you say that IQ tests must be faulty if all ethnicities do not show the same distribution. The alternative hypothesis, in support of which there is a vast amount of data, is that different ethnicities vary in mean IQ. One dares not even discuss those at the low end, but few object to data indicating that European Jews show the highest mean IQ, followed by East Asians, followed by Europeans. The various IQ tests have been modified for decades in efforts to change these results by doing away with all cultural bias, but the relative rankings remain. In fact, phsyiolgical measures (reaction time) are highly correlated with IQ and closely reflect the ethnic rankings of traditional pencil and paper tests.

Although no academics are willing to destroy their careers by broaching the subject, these differences have profound social and international implications and must eventually be honestly confronted.

No thinking person would support the death penalty if there is any remote doubt about guilt, but in most heinous crimes there is no question about the perpetrator.  It makes a mockery of the sanctity of life to afford such criminals a lesser sentence than they inflicted upon victims and their families.

But what of those who sentence innocent children to death or a terrible life due to Zika? Should they be exempt from the death penalty?

Oh, they're Republicans.

Punishment is not revenge.  Society punishes offenses after the fact to deter the original offense ... In the past, punishment took other forms -- but usually as deterrence; even the payment of weregild was intended as deterrence.  Using jail as punishment has the side effect of making it more difficult (or impossible) for the offender to repeat the offense for a certain period of time.

John Brown, our states are not equal in education or in appreciation of humanity.

The red states are much more likely to be gerrymandered or controlled by religious fanatics. We were created as a secular nation by enlightened people who were suspicious of religion for valid reasons.

I doubt it. Here are some facts about the Clinton Foundation.

http://www.factcheck.org/2015/06/where-does-clinton-foundation-money-go/

More Judicial Watch mishigass. Time to move on ...

Your avatar is a SWIRL candidate. There are nine letters in his first and middle names.
